Next, I placed a coffee filter in a funnel and dripped water at about 100C through it. I left the product on a hotplate to reflux for about 10 minutes, then I poured the solution into a ceramic beaker (that has the periodic table printed on the side). Next, I added about 10 grams of sucrose and a cold buffer solution of lactose, casein calcium phosphate, and lipids. It was good…

Quantification of caffeine is something everyone has to do at the university for pharmacy. All in all the method is pretty much the same, except you do have to shake it a good amount. You said that there is a possibility to make an emulsion. Well thats true, but the emulsion is not stable and will disperse again after a short time, overwise use a bit more DCM. You can also cook the coffee for a longer time, those 15 minutes are not enough. Also try to invest into a Rotavapor, just cooking DCM is not a good idea at all (I hope you got some air-filtering unit above it or a digestor). We use Sodiumsulfate instead of a molecular sieve as drying agent for the DCM. We didn't recrystalise, because we made titrations with it. Reason is also because its purity won't be that good (far from 99%). Cheaper to just buy the pure caffeine from your trusted merchant / pharmacy.

I would start by acidifying the water used to prepare the coffee, boiling, then filtering.  Then you add the sodium carbonate and organic solvent and shake in the sep funnel. Reason his yield was so low is due to the very outdated extraction method. Far easier method is using the activated carbon method, steep coffee then filter out coffee grinds. Run liquid through pressed active carbon, break up carbon once dry to soak in ethanol, mix equal parts with muriatic acid & watch the caffine crystalize together. Then strain discarding toxic liquid (contains all the coffee oils too) add strained solids to water and simmer for while, strain one last time & gently boil down liquid to result in anhydrous caffine

Nice video! We compared caffeine content years ago at varsity on different beverages. Contrary to popular belief, a shot of espresso had the lowest caffeine content of everything we tested (lower than tea, instant coffee and perculated coffee, etc). This was mainly due to the short infusion time when extracting espresso from the machine (20 seconds). The type of roast also influenced the caffeine content - the darker the roast, the stronger it tastes, but the less caffeine it contains due to longer roasting. So if you want to stay awake, leave the espresso and opt for a weak tasting, but "powerful" pale roasted perculated coffee.

Caffeine is a methylxanthine, a pseudoallocaloid, so we must apply an extractive method consistent with alkaloid. Alkaloids are salt-form and the free base form. To improve extraction, one should work with these molecular properties. When extracted in aqueous medium, an acid must be added to bring the protonation of the molecule and thus the caffeine would be very solubility in water. If you want to extract it in organic solvent add base to remove the proton from the molecular thus making it soluble in organic phase. And it is still possible to alternate these phases to pre-purify alkaloids.

I have some suggestions for you. After you extracted the crude caffeine with DCM, you can probably add 2M HCl into the organic layer until the mixture is slightly acidic. You then keep the aqueous layer and add 2M of NaOH until the pH of the mixture is about 8 and extract with DCM again. So you will get rid of most of the non-polar or less polar organic impurities. Besides, when you do the filtration, you should heat up the beaker and funnel to do a hot filtration. If you have a sintered funned and vacuum flask, it will be much better.
